data.title: Changed missed ActorInfo.Traits.Contains => ActorInfo.HasTraitInfo
data.body:
Somehow (possibly by rebasing) I missed a couple in `OpenRA.Mods.Common/AI/BaseBuilder.cs`.
The change to is both for completeness and my next PR to finish wrapping of `ActorInfo.Traits` and make it private.

data.title: Fixed TS crane overlay's last frame hiding idle overlay
data.body:
TS crane overlay's last frame no longer overlaps idle overlay. `WithBuildingPlacedOverlay` is now only visible while playing the animation, rather than sticking around.

Fixes #9319.

data.title: Skip non-existing player references
data.body: fixes #9364

data.title: Changed make.ps1 test order
data.body:
- changed make.ps1 yaml test order to match makefile/Travis
- shortened `dependencies` command to `deps`

data.title: Adds FindActorsInAnnulus and tweaks AI scan for enemies
data.body:
An attempt to improve performance of AI scans for nearby enemies by only checking the last third of the radius if nothing was found in the first 2/3.

Additionally gave ChooseBuildLocation check a minimum distance of 2 cells, as the center cell and the 8 adjacent cells will normally be occupied by the construction yard (or its bib) anyway.

data.title: Added thread-affinity checks to SDL2 renderer
data.body: If a call is made into a graphics resource that has thread-affinity, from a thread other than the one that created the graphics device, an exception will now be thrown to make debugging easier.

data.title: Replace only use of Linq syntax
data.body:
`Harvester.ClosestProc(Actor self, Actor ignore)` is the only place where Linq syntax is used instead of writing calls to the Linq methods directly.

This should fit better with the rest of the code base.

data.title: Distribute large calculations over multiple ticks where possible
data.body:
I got this idea while playing D2k (the original, not our mod). Harvesters were showing a noticable delay before some actions. What I suspect is that rather than stuffing whole decision making/path calculation into single ticks/frames, they would simply limit the amount of computation per tick and distribute it over multiple ticks when necessary.

If we identified cases where the result of the computation is not immediately required by something else (or where it's easy to refactor it that way) we might be able to avoid some showstopper lag spikes even without changing the total amount of computing power required by the operation in question.

Potential candidates (there are certainly more):
- AI base builder placement decision (particularly if there is a lack of space)
- AI attack decisions
- possibly pathfinding
## <bountysource-plugin>

Want to back this issue? **[Post a bounty on it!](https://www.bountysource.com/issues/26780973-distribute-large-calculations-over-multiple-ticks-where-possible?utm_campaign=plugin&utm_content=tracker%2F36085&utm_medium=issues&utm_source=github)** We accept bounties via [Bountysource](https://www.bountysource.com/?utm_campaign=plugin&utm_content=tracker%2F36085&utm_medium=issues&utm_source=github).
</bountysource-plugin>

data.title: Polish D2k some more to match original
data.body:
- [x] the grenadier's grenades were originally much smaller, on bleed it uses ornithopter bomb images
- [x] bleed's Quad rocket trail should actually be the rocket's explosion, while the trail should use the same graphics as the bazooka.
- [x] the explosion of the siege tank howitzer cannon is far too large, it used a much smaller explosion animation in the original.
- [ ] when just targeting ground and not a specific target, all weapons were quite inaccurate. We should consider an AccuracyByTargetType kind of feature, because a similar system was used in TD to make tank cannons less accurate vs. infantry.

data.title: HealUnitsCrateAction.Activate() use ActorsWithTrait<Health>()
data.body:
`ActorsWithTrait<Health>()` only accesses actors with a `Health` trait as opposed to going through looking for those with a `Health` trait.
It is the only place I found using `World.Actors` and `.Trait[OrDefault]<TTrait>` instead of `ActorsWithTrait`.

data.title: Fix husks of chronosphered actors not being teleported back
data.body:
Fixes #9349

This may regress horribly. I'm not sure in which other cases `teleporter` was null before. All of those (if any) would be affected by this change.

Edit: it looks like using the `Chronoshift*Init`s would be the only case where `teleporter` could be null, which means only husks and custom maps using those inits would be affected.

data.title: Extends MapChooserLogic.mapFilter to match against PlayerCount
data.body:
`MapChooserLogic.EnumerateMaps` currently matches `mapFilter` against map's `Title` and `Author`.
This PR extends `Where` predicate to match against `PlayerCount`. 

When choosing a map I often like to browse maps by number of players.

data.title: D2k : Cannot select all of a certain unit depending where it has been built from.
data.body:
Okay this is a bit difficult to explain. It is a Dune 2000 bug.

Issue: All units aren't being selected. Example: Click on a combat tank then use the select all unit hotkey. It will select all the combat tanks that were built from the factory, or the starport, but not both. You will see combat tanks that haven't been inlcuded in the selection, those are from the other production facility. To select those too you must shift click one of the other combat tanks and then use the select all unit hotkey.

data.title: Fixed pooling of layers used for pathfinding
data.body:
The previous implementation:
- Was failing to dispose of pooled layers.
- Was using a finalizer to allow undisposed layers to be reused.

This means all pooled layers are kept alive indefinitely until the map changes. If the finalizer is slow for any reason then the pathfiinder will allocate new layers when the pool runs out. Since these new layers are eventually stuffed back into the pool when the finalizer does run, this can theoretically leak unbounded memory until the pool goes out of scope. In practice it would leak tens of megabytes.

The new implementation ensures layers are disposed and pooled correctly to allow proper memory reuse. It also introduces some safeguards against memory leaks:
- A cap is set on the number of pooled layers. If more concurrent layers are needed than this, then the excess layers will not be pooled but instead be allowed to be garbage collected.
- No finalizer. An implementation that fails to call dispose simply allows the layer to be garbage collected instead.

---

Proposed changelog: Lump in with "Improved in-game performance and memory usage."

data.title: Fix a crash when the stnk of TS is cloaking
data.body: Fixes #9353.

data.title: Added a LineImpactProjectile (Attempt 2)
data.body:
Attempt number 2 at  #6252

New projectile can create multiple weapon impacts along its travel vector.
(i.e. apply all warheads effects at multiple positions as it travels).

It has a leading head position, and a following tail position, and renders a beam (LaserZap) between these two positions. Weapon impacts are created (iteratively over the distance) between the head and tail, at definable intervals.

The tail position (origin of beam) tracks the firing actor until it detaches and travels on its own. This means that if you move the firing actor while the beam is firing, it does track correctly.

You can currently tell it to:
- Define how many ticks the tail must lag the head (i.e. the length of the travelling beam).
- Create an impact every WRange, every X ticks, between head and tail.
- Only create an impact if at least WRange away from its source.
- Only create an impact if at least within WRange of its target.
- Keep traveling for up to WRange beyond its target.
- Have damage falloff (essentially passed as a firepowermodifier to the weapon during impact) that
  - Has a WRange before it starts
  - Has a WRange at which it reaches maximum falloff
  - Has a maximum falloff.

Was based off mixture of Bullet and LaserZap.

Does NOT support
- A proper rendering engine to make it look like something other than a basic beam. (Currently looks fine for instant-hit beams. But slow-moving beams are ugly.)

I still have to do:
- The target is a static position, so if you fire at a moving actor, even while the firing actor is still busy emitting the beam, the head does not 'track' the target. Not sure how to do this. (Would like to make this an Info setting.)
- ~~Add Ray-casting, finding all actors within the bounds of the beam's length and width. #8186~~
- ~~Make warheads apply to actors directly, ignoring warhead spreads.~~ (Causes crashes and unexpected behavior. Will require some warhead refactoring, or at least a new warhead type.)
- ~~When the actor is ordered to stop, the beam should stop emitting if still busy.~~
- ~~When the actor dies, the beam should stop emitting if still busy.~~

Still to be tested:
- ~~That walls properly block the beam if the beam is blockable.~~
- ~~That the projectile properly works for 'short' beams, such as D2K sonic ball.~~ Works, though very short beams render as practically invisible.
- ~~That the projectile properly works for brief instant-hit beams, such as TS railguns.~~ Works

Closes  #4458.

I've attempted to apply it to the D2K sonic tank, and the TS disruptor tank, but balancing needs work.

@pchote: I've re-read and attempted to apply all the requests in #6252. But given that this is over an year overdue, I suspect much has changed and the requirements need revisiting.

Sidenote: I apologize for dropping the ball on this last year.

data.title: Remove redundant IBodyOrientation[Info] & replace with BodyOrientation[Info]
data.body:
`BodyOrientation[Info]` is the only implementation of `IBodyOrientation[Info]`. Having the redundant interfaces provides inconsistent code (currently uses both to do the same thing). That also has the effect of making `TraitDictionary` keep two identical pairs of lists for the `BodyOrientation` traits and their actors.
I found 9 info classes with `var body = init.Actor.Traits.Get<BodyOrientationInfo>();` in a preview render method:

``` c#
RenderVoxels
    RenderPreview(ActorPreviewInitializer init)

WithBarrelInfo
    RenderPreviewSprites(ActorPreviewInitializer init, RenderSpritesInfo rs, string image, int facings, PaletteReference p)

WithIdleOverlayInfo
    RenderPreviewSprites(ActorPreviewInitializer init, RenderSpritesInfo rs, string image, int facings, PaletteReference p)

WithParachuteInfo
    RenderPreviewSprites(ActorPreviewInitializer init, RenderSpritesInfo rs, string image, int facings, PaletteReference p)

WithRotorInfo
    RenderPreviewSprites(ActorPreviewInitializer init, RenderSpritesInfo rs, string image, int facings, PaletteReference p)

WithTurretInfo
    RenderPreviewSprites(ActorPreviewInitializer init, RenderSpritesInfo rs, string image, int facings, PaletteReference p)

WithVoxelBodyInfo
    RenderPreviewVoxels(ActorPreviewInitializer init, RenderVoxelsInfo rv, string image, WRot orientation, int facings, PaletteReference p)

WithVoxelTurretInfo
    RenderPreviewVoxels(ActorPreviewInitializer init, RenderVoxelsInfo rv, string image, WRot orientation, int facings, PaletteReference p)

WithVoxelUnloadBodyInfo
    RenderPreviewVoxels(ActorPreviewInitializer init, RenderVoxelsInfo rv, string image, WRot orientation, int facings, PaletteReference p)
```

`WithVoxel*Info` use `RenderVoxelsInfo` which had `Requires<IBodyOrientationInfo>`.

data.title: Catch exception when hosting server on busy port
data.body:
First PR, haven't coded in C# before. But the changes should be fairly simple.

Closes #9354

Suggested changelog: "Now displays an error when attempting to host a game on a busy port instead of crashing".

data.title: Crash when hosting a game if selected port is not free
data.body:
In any mod, if one attempts to host a game on a busy port, we crash with:

```
Exception of type `System.Net.Sockets.SocketException`: Address already in use
  at System.Net.Sockets.Socket.Bind (System.Net.EndPoint local_end) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at System.Net.Sockets.TcpListener.Start (Int32 backlog) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at System.Net.Sockets.TcpListener.Start () [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenRA.Server.Server..ctor (System.Net.IPEndPoint endpoint, OpenRA.ServerSettings settings, OpenRA.ModData modData) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenRA.Game.CreateServer (OpenRA.ServerSettings settings) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenRA.Mods.Common.Widgets.Logic.ServerCreationLogic.CreateAndJoin () [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenRA.Mods.Common.Widgets.ButtonWidget.<ButtonWidget>m__A (MouseInput _) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenRA.Mods.Common.Widgets.ButtonWidget.HandleMouseInput (MouseInput mi) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenRA.Widgets.Widget.HandleMouseInputOuter (MouseInput mi) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenRA.Widgets.Ui.HandleInput (MouseInput mi) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenRA.DefaultInputHandler+<OnMouseInput>c__AnonStorey2.<>m__0 () [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenRA.Sync.CheckSyncUnchanged[Boolean] (OpenRA.World world, System.Func`1 fn) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenRA.DefaultInputHandler.OnMouseInput (MouseInput input) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenRA.Renderer.Sdl2.Sdl2Input.PumpInput (IInputHandler inputHandler) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenRA.Renderer.Sdl2.Sdl2GraphicsDevice.PumpInput (IInputHandler inputHandler) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenRA.Graphics.Renderer.EndFrame (IInputHandler inputHandler) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenRA.Game.RenderTick () [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenRA.Game.Loop () [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenRA.Game.Run () [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenRA.Program.Run (System.String[] args) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
  at OpenRA.Program.Main (System.String[] args) [0x00000] in <filename unknown>:0 
AL lib: (EE) alc_cleanup: 1 device not closed
```

PR incoming.

data.title: Crash when stealth tank stealths
data.body:
```
Exception of type `System.InvalidOperationException`: Palette `cloak` does not exist
```

Regression from #8996.  Unfortunately this PR removed the lint attribute that would have caught this error at the same time it made it refer to an invalid palette.

data.title: Confusing UI in map browser
data.body:
![ui_tabs](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10639257/9875592/744bf918-5baf-11e5-9487-337964852aec.jpg)

Since color of button A is the same as background at location B (and also because the button is so close to the "maps folder area") it seems as if the button labeled **"Custom Maps"** is a **currently active tab** displaying maps below. Only by content I know that is not so. The maps shown are the "Official Maps". It's confusing.

I suggest more space between the button(s) and the "map folder area" (B)
and perhaps a different background  for  "map folder" (location B).

data.title: Units & buildings under GAP are auto targeted when GPS is available
data.body:
(Playtest 20150830)
If player A's units & buildings are masked by a GAP generator, player B does't have vision of those units or their GPS icons (correct behaviour), however player B's units still auto target (attack move) units and buildings under the GAP.

Test replay: http://www.megafileupload.com/9l4h/GPSunderGAP.orarep

data.title: Add the flameguy death animation
data.body:

Note two: Does someone have better names for `IHuskModifier` and `IHuskCreated`?
(That are just internals, but we removed `husk` from the rest of the code, too.)
